name: UCI Diabetes 130-US hospitals (1999–2008)
description:
The dataset represents ten years (1999-2008) of clinical care at 130 US hospitals and integrated delivery networks. Each row concerns hospital records of patients diagnosed with diabetes, who underwent laboratory, medications, and stayed up to 14 days. The goal is to determine the early readmission of the patient within 30 days of discharge.
The problem is important for the following reasons. Despite high-quality evidence showing improved clinical outcomes for diabetic patients who receive various preventive and therapeutic interventions, many patients do not receive them. This can be partially attributed to arbitrary diabetes management in hospital environments, which fail to attend to glycemic control. Failure to provide proper diabetes care not only increases the managing costs for the hospitals (as the patients are readmitted) but also impacts the morbidity and mortality of the patients, who may face complications associated with diabetes.
citation: Impact of HbA1c Measurement on Hospital Readmission Rates: Analysis of 70,000 Clinical Database Patient Record. Beata Strack, Jonathan DeShazo, Chris Gennings, Juan Olmo, Sebastian Ventura, Krzysztof Cios, John Clore. BioMed Research International, vol. 2014. 2014

variableMeasured.name: race
variableMeasured.description: Values: Caucasian, Asian, African American, Hispanic, and other

variableMeasured.name: gender
variableMeasured.description: Administrative sex/gender

variableMeasured.name: age
variableMeasured.description: Age (10-year bins)

variableMeasured.name: weight
variableMeasured.description: Weight in pounds.

variableMeasured.name: admission_type_id
variableMeasured.description: Admission type (coded integer)

variableMeasured.name: discharge_disposition_id
variableMeasured.description: Discharge disposition (coded integer)

variableMeasured.name: admission_source_id
variableMeasured.description: Admission source (coded integer)

variableMeasured.name: time_in_hospital
variableMeasured.description: Length of stay (days)

variableMeasured.name: payer_code
variableMeasured.description: Integer identifier corresponding to 23 distinct values, for example, Blue Cross/Blue Shield, Medicare, and self-pay

variableMeasured.name: medical_specialty
variableMeasured.description: Integer identifier of a specialty of the admitting physician, corresponding to 84 distinct values, for example, cardiology, internal medicine, family/general practice, and surgeon

variableMeasured.name: num_lab_procedures
variableMeasured.description: Number of lab tests performed during the encounter

variableMeasured.name: num_procedures
variableMeasured.description: Number of procedures (other than lab tests) performed during the encounter

variableMeasured.name: num_medications
variableMeasured.description: Number of distinct generic names administered during the encounter

variableMeasured.name: number_outpatient
variableMeasured.description: Number of outpatient visits of the patient in the year preceding the encounter

variableMeasured.name: number_emergency
variableMeasured.description: Number of emergency visits of the patient in the year preceding the encounter

variableMeasured.name: number_inpatient
variableMeasured.description: Number of inpatient visits of the patient in the year preceding the encounter

variableMeasured.name: diag_1
variableMeasured.description: Primary diagnosis (ICD-9-CM)

variableMeasured.name: diag_2
variableMeasured.description: Secondary diagnosis (ICD-9-CM)

variableMeasured.name: diag_3
variableMeasured.description: Tertiary diagnosis (ICD-9-CM)

variableMeasured.name: number_diagnoses
variableMeasured.description: Number of diagnoses entered to the system

variableMeasured.name: max_glu_serum
variableMeasured.description: Maximum glucose result (categorical)

variableMeasured.name: A1Cresult
variableMeasured.description: Hemoglobin A1c result (categorical)

variableMeasured.name: metformin
variableMeasured.description: Metformin therapy status

variableMeasured.name: repaglinide
variableMeasured.description: The feature indicates whether the drug was prescribed or there was a change in the dosage. Values: up if the dosage was increased during the encounter, down if the dosage was decreased, steady if the dosage did not change, and no if the drug was not prescribed
